data.title: What if Guns n' Roses had released a followup to Appetite for Destruction in 1989?
data.meta_description: It took them four years to get from Appetite to Use Your Illusions, but if they wanted to, they could've easily had released a record in between...
data.text:
It took them four years to get from Appetite to Use Your Illusions, but if they wanted to, they could've easily had released a record in between Appetite and the Illusions. I mean, aside from the three originals from Lies, here's what they had written before April 1989:

Patience

Used to Love Her

One in a Million

The Garden - written in 1986

Don't Cry - written in 1985

November Rain - written in 1986

You Could Be Mine - written right before Appetite

Perfect Crime - written in

Bad Obsession - written in 1986

Back Off, Bitch - written in 1982

Ain't Going Down - written right before Appetite

Yesterdays - written in 1985

Knockin' on Heaven's Door - played live in 1988

With all of that in mind, in a recent blog post, I sequenced what such an album could look like, and this is what I ended up with:

GUNS N' ROSES - PERFECT CRIME (1989)

You Could Be Mine (Use Your Illusion II)

The Garden (Use Your Illusion I)

Don't Cry (Use Your Illusion I)

Bad Obsession (Use Your Illusion I)

Perfect Crime (Use Your Illusion I)

Knockin' on Heaven's Door (Use Your Illusion II)

-

Used to Love Her (GN'R Lies)

Patience (GN'R Lies)

Back Off Bitch (Use Your Illusion I)

Yesterdays (Use Your Illusion II)

November Rain (Use Your Illusion I)

One in a Million (GN'R Lies)

What do you think: Would it have been a good thing, had they released such an album in 1989? Would it help their momentum or oversaturate them for good?

I love these G'n'R what-ifs. Your 'Perfect Crime' album would've been a killer although I feel that a 'main' album release with One in a Million on it (as opposed to what was the more low-key Lies album) would have led to an even bigger controversy.

Even though November Rain is Axl's pet song, I would much prefer that it had been kept for an Axl Rose solo album where he could've lived out all his singer/songwriter Elton John fantasies. I like it, but the song and especially the video were symptomatic of the absurd bloated mess that Guns n Roses became in the 90s.

These threads are really interesting. Before I found them, I actually looked at this a few times over the years and then recently I spent a fair bit of time on it!

My approach was looking back in time at how it should have happened and what is believable to me as an improvement at that time. It’s not me picking my favourite songs, then or 30 years later to make one album or wishing there were different songs, versions or personnel involved, it’s using what was released and re-imagining history! A lot of time was spent on sequencing/pacing/timing etc.

It’s clear those 30ish recordings were ‘it’ and were going to have to last a very long time. The collection was the collection – a lot of fast songs, a lot of slow songs…short, long, simple, complex… Picking a balance of each and releasing them a year or two apart is probably what artists usually do, but that’s not very exciting.

The albums released as they were though never made sense to me – two different albums with the same name released on the same day? My then age group of 16-24 bought a lot of records and we didn’t understand it – some people only had one (?), some people didn’t like one (?), I couldn’t afford both so had neither (!) until I loaned off a friend, and then copying to tape was hard work!

The albums with different names and/or styles, a double album or one ‘brilliant’ album are all better alternatives, but I think there’s a problem with achieving the latter – the songs (and specifically the timings)…what were singles (what weren’t), what were performed live (what weren’t), what were people’s favourites at the time (against now). Picking singles would miss off the best songs, and the best songs might present issues playing live and result in an album length of about 7-8 which wouldn’t have been acceptable at that point. An individual’s favourites of each could rule out 100% of someone else’s etc, etc.

With all this in mind I offer three better scenarios. I hope it provides some interest.

Use Your Illusion as a good old fashioned double album which, all things considered, I still believe is what should have happened. The songs still suggest that to me….just a few less of them! This would have been followed down the line by a Civil War ep (like there was) pulling together 2 songs featured elsewhere and 2 highlighting Izzy and Duff).

Two separate albums at different times developing a more gradual and appropriate transition of sound between Appetite and Illusion (inspired by my wife’s opinion of how it should have gone and the titles of each are hers!)

Improved versions of both albums if there really had to be a Use Your Illusion I+II as it happened.

In more primitive forms, the songs on the original post could maybe have worked for a follow up, but in my opinion, based on the songs in the form that I know them from their respective releases, most of it would've, to me, sounded like a snoozefest on the heels of Appetite. That may have been the way they were going anyway, but a single album, two years after AFD, containing three acoustic tracks, an okay but unnecessary cover song, and four tracks on the more ballad-y side, with various levels of bloat...I don't know.

I'm not really familiar with any of the demo versions of any of these songs, just the versions from the proper albums, so maybe there is something there. But if they had a pile of songs with the energy of Perfect Crime or You Could be Mine and included Patience and I guess one of those ballad-y tracks, though I'm not super into any of them--maybe Yesterdays--that would be good for sure.

I often fantasize about GNR having another more Appetite style album by the end of the 80s.
